captions.text:
Good morning Hank, it's Tuesday. I want to
talk today about why healthcare costs in the

United States are so phenomenally, fascinatingly
expensive, but first I have to blow your mind:

Alright, so you've probably heard that the
reason that people enjoy "free" healthcare

in Australia and the UK and Canada, etc, etc
is that they pay higher taxes. That money

then goes into a big pot and is used to pay
for people's healthcare, but in fact, in the

US, we spend more tax money per capita on
healthcare than Germany, Australia, the UK,
or Canada.

That's right Hank: you pay more in taxes for
healthcare than you would if you were British,

and in exchange for those taxes, you get no
healthcare.

In fact, only about 28% of Americans get their
health insurance through government funded

programs, mostly poor people, old people,
and Congresspeople. But as you can see in

this graph our private healthcare spending
(most Americans are privately insured through

their employers) is WAY higher than anywhere
else in the world.

In total, the US currently spends about 18% of its gross 
domestic product on healthcare costs.
Australia by comparison? 9%.

Why is this? Well because everything costs
more, which seems obvious, but apparently

isn't, because every article you read is like
"Oh it's because of malpractice insurance"

or "it's because we're obese" or we go to
the doctor too much or people are prescribed
too many medications. Well, not really.

It's because everything costs more. A hip
replacement in Belgium costs $13,000. In the

US it's often over $100,000. Colonoscopies
average over $1100 a piece in the US; in Switzerland

they're $655. And on average a month of the
drug Lipitor will cost you $124 if you live
in the US. If you live in New Zealand? $7.

Now we are also—not to brag—richer than
all of these countries, so it makes sense

that we should spend a little more on healthcare.
But we don't spend a little more. We spend

a ton more. And vitally, we don't get anything
for that money, which means we are essentially

paying people to dig holes and then fill those
holes back up. Like we don't live longer—in

fact we're 33rd in life expectancy—and in
everything from asthma to cancer, according

to one recent nonpartisan study, American healthcare
outcomes are "not notably superior."

So why are we spending all of this money for
nothing? Well first, let's discuss some of
the problems that are not actually problems.

For instance, the problem is not so-called
"overutilization:" the idea that Americans

go to the doctor more and get more tests and
spend more time in hospitals. We know this

because Americans actually go to the doctor
less than Europeans and spend much less time

in hospitals, although to be fair, you can
stay in a Dutch hospital for seven nights

for what it costs to stay in an American hospital
for one night, so no wonder we're hesitant.

Also it is not because we're sicker than other
people. Everyone likes to blame obesity on

our rising healthcare costs, but yeah, no.
That argument is just not supported by data.

For one thing, disease prevalence does not
affect healthcare costs that much. And for

another thing, while we do have more obesity
in the United States, which sometimes leads

to health problems, we have fewer smokers
and less alcohol consumption (really? Apparently

yes). So that saves us a little money, and
if you compare us to like the British or the
French, in the end it's probably a wash.

Hank, the truth, as usual, is complex. Like,
there are obvious inefficiencies in our healthcare

system. For instance, not everyone has insurance.
If you don't have insurance, you still get

healthcare, but you're responsible for paying
for that healthcare, which often you can't

do, so you end up going bankrupt. That sucks
for you, obviously, because you're bankrupt,

but it also sucks for the rest of us because
we have to pay not only for your care, but

also for all the money the hospital spent
trying to get you to pay for your care. Also

the only options available to uninsured people
are usually the most expensive options, like

emergency rooms, which is just BANANAS. But those
inefficiencies are hard to measure. Fortunately,
there are things we can measure.

So like I said before, because the US is one
of the richest countries in the world, you

would expect us to pay a little more for healthcare
than most people. The question is, when do

we pay MORE than you would expect us to pay,
and that turns out to be pretty interesting.

Let's start with malpractice and so-called
"defensive medicine." The idea here is that

doctors are scared of huge malpractice suits
so they order a lot of unnecessary tests

in order to, like, cover their butts. That
does contribute to our healthcare costs, like

there are more MRI and CT scans in the US
than anywhere else. However, there are a bunch

of states like Texas that have passed tort
reform to limit malpractice suits, and in

those states healthcare costs have dropped
by an average of a whopping 0.1%. The biggest

estimates for the total costs of defensive
medicine put it at around 55 billion dollars, which

is a lot of money, but only 2% of our total
healthcare costs.

Another smallish factor: doctors (and to a
lesser extent, nurses) are paid more in the

US than they are in other countries, and by
my possibly-faulty math we end up spending

about 75 billion dollars more than you would
expect us to there.

And then we have the cost of insurance and
administration costs, like paperwork and marketing

and negotiating prices. That's about 90 billion
dollars more than you would expect us to spend.

We spend about $100 billion more than you
would expect on drugs, not so much because

we take MORE of them, but because the ones
we take cost more per pill.

Okay, and now for the big one. I'm gonna lump
inpatient and outpatient care together, because

in the US we do a lot of things as outpatient
procedures, like gallbladder surgeries, that

are often inpatient procedures in other hospitals.
We're just gonna make a big ball [gestures].

That big ball is $500 billion more than what
you would expect given the size of our economy.
Per year.

Why? Because in the United States we do not negotiate
as aggressively as other countries do with

healthcare providers and drug manufacturers
and medical device makers. So like in the

UK the government goes out to all the people
who make artificial hips and says "One of

you is going to get to make a crapton of fake
hips for everybody who is covered by the NHS

here in the United Kingdom. But you better
make sure your hips are safe, and you better

make sure that they are cheap, because otherwise
we're going to give our business to a different

company." And then all the fake hip companies
are motivated to offer really low prices because

it's a really huge contract. Like think if
your company got to put hips inside of

everyone in England and Scotland and Wales
and Northern Ireland (I guess not everyone.
Just the people who need hips).

But in the US we don't have any of that centralized
negotiation, so we don't have as much leverage.

The only big exception is Medicare, the government-funded
healthcare for old people, which, not coincidentally,
always gets the lowest prices.

So basically, Hank, in the United States,
providers charge whatever they think they

can get away with, and they can get away with
a lot, because it's really difficult to put

a price on, like, not dying. This is a phenomenon
called "inelastic demand," like if you tell

me that this drug will save my life costs
$7 a month, I will pay you $7 a month for

it. If you tell me that it costs $124 a month,
I will find a way to find $124 a month to

pay for it. You can't negotiate effectively
on your own behalf for healthcare services

because you NEED them. And not like you need
a Macbook Air or the new season of Sherlock,

but actual, physical need (I guess it is like
the new season of Sherlock).

So basically, Hank, until and unless we can
negotiate as effectively with the people providing

healthcare as Australians and British people
do, US healthcare costs will continue to rise

faster than anywhere else in the world and
we WON'T get better healthcare outcomes.

Hank, I know this video is long, although
it could have been much longer, but I am so

tired of people offering up simple explanations
for what's wrong with our healthcare system.

They say "Oh, it's malpractice," or "it's
doctors who must also be businesspeople" or

"it's insurance companies" or "it's insane
rules for who can GET insurance." It's drug

companies, it's government bureaucracy, it's
an inability to negotiate prices. Yes, yes,

yes, yes, and YES! It is all of those things
and more! It is not a simple problem, there

will not be a simple solution, but it is probably
the biggest single drag on the American economy

and it's vital that we grapple with it meaningfully
instead of just treating healthcare costs
as political theatre.

So I hope I've at least introduced the complexity
of the problem. I've put some thoroughly nonpartisan

links in the doobly-doo for further reading.
Hank, welcome back to the United States. As

you can see, everything is peachy here. I'll
see you on Friday.
Friendly reminder, educational videos are allowed to be more than four minutes long. All of the people who are commenting about how

punished I am did not watch to the end of the video.
I feel dizzy.

title: Why Are American Health Care Costs So High?

comments.text:
Actually according to other OECD studies, US has the highest life 
expectancy of OECD nations if the data is standardize to excludes violent 
death. Just to mention that US also has relatively higher murder rate, 
motor vehicle accident rate, and participation in the wars than other OECD 
nations. US also has more centenarian per 100,000 population than many 
European countries, including Switzerland and Finland.

Does US healthcare system has a great flaws? Yes, when we're talking about 
health coverage and cost, but does that means that Americans are less 
healthy? Likely no according to the aforementioned studies. Is it important 
to improve it? It have to be.﻿

comments.author: 1toneboy

comments.text:
You wanna know the leading reason. It's all that, with the leading reason 
being massive copyright laws, patents laws, and strict government 
regulation. Difference between us and Europe is how insane our copyrights 
are. Get rid of that and prices will start dropping quickly. Also Inelastic 
demand is only true if only one company, one insurer and one hospital chain 
has a monopoly over everything, for so long there are at least two, there 
will still be one person charging lower than the other. Technically it does 
exist though, but that can be blamed on again, our strict copyright/patent 
laws which essential do give a monopoly over certain drugs, the only thing 
trying to lower prices is hospitals and insurance companies.﻿
comments.author: Aaron Morton

Totally sick of Health Care Costs including what the insurance companies

Then look at their lobbies in Washington.
It's the greed.
Plain and simple.
They hold our lives hostage.﻿
comments.author: Adolph Hare

comments.text:

comments.author: Chris Myfckingprivacythanks

comments.text:
In 1965 LBJ signed Medicare and Medicaid programs into law. The lower cost 
negotiated by government for these fixed cost low income programs isn't 
absorbed by hospitals it's dumped onto the market in the form of higher 
cost for those with health insurance. Similarly issues exist with indigent 
care were hospitals must absorb these costs. 

https://www.cms.gov/About-CMS/Agency-Information/History/index.html?redirect=/history/

From the 1930-1960's health care cost were reasonable by the late 1960's we 
started to see  higher increases by 1975 it was 4% a year by the mid 1980's 
it was 10% after implementation of these programs  

http://mises.org/sites/default/files/holly1.jpg

The drug approval process takes on average 12 years and costs companies 
over US$350 million the initial permit is 1 million dollars﻿
comments.author: Randy Hyde

comments.text:
First off, good video with a lot of good information but it does contain an 
immense amount of commentary as fact that simply isn't factual.

For instance, the "fake hip" bit about must be safe and must be cheap. The 
UK has experienced massive problems with its limiting of choices to 
patients in artificial hip replacement with thousands possible tens of 
thousands having to be reversed and replaced, causing pain and tumors after 
poisoning the blood with chromium and cobalt. You left out how giving a 
monopoly contract and taking away health care choice from the patient 
causes a lot of problems, sometimes fatal.

Health care isn't this monolithic good or service and to call the demand 
"inelastic" can be deceptive. It is only inelastic when it is life saving 
or critical.  People decide all the time in health care based on prices.  
Sometimes those prices are monetary, this pill costs X but I'm not hurting 
that bad so I'll let it heal on its own.  But in other countries sometimes 
that price is in time, ie, I have to wait 83 days for an MRI or 3 months 
for a specialist or 7 hours for an appointment.   I can literally get in 
for an MRI this afternoon in my hometown of Bowling Green, Kentucky USA  
whereas the average wait time in Ottawa is nearly 3 months for a 
non-emergency MRI.

But more importantly is a conversation about substitution.  Where I can get 
expensive diabetes drugs in the US people in Greece substitute the less 
costly (to the government) alternative of getting their foot amputated.  
Yes, we spend more but we also get better Quality of Life Years. Is it 
worth it?  Apparently so or people wouldn't be buying it.﻿
comments.author: Greg Jent

comments.text:
+Jonny Salvage The US has higher cancer survival rates than any country in 
the world.  If people were really dying because they can't get treatment 
then this wouldn't be the case. People with heart disease live longer here 
as well.  We get more choices, better treatment and faster treatment.  The 
only time the US system slacks is when people are put on socialized 
medicine, ie medicaid. 

So your assessment about hundreds of millions of Americans losing out is 
beyond ridiculous.
comments.author: Greg Jent

comments.text:
+Greg Jent Nonesense. First, you don't take away choice from people by 
creating a universal healthcare system. Private companies still exist for 
those who chose it. Second, people really don't need 'choice' in 
healthcare. They need to be treated instead of being left with a choice of 
dying or being hit with an enormous bill like they are in the US. Universal 
healthcare is supported by virtually every economic model. The only reason 
that the US fails to have one is because the companies essentially 
bribe/lobby republicans which prevents any move in this direction. In the 
end it is the hundreds of millions of Americans who lose out.
comments.author: Jonny Salvage

comments.text:
The funny thing about this is that the UK has similar tax rates to the USA 
in some states, also if you are on average income in the UK the amount of 
healthcare expenditure on you over your lifetime far outweighs the amount 
of taxes you pay for healthcare. From an average individuals point of view 
it actually leaves you better off-I am also arguing from the point of 
someone who has private healthcare.﻿
comments.author: Huw Robinson

comments.text:
+Huw Robinson Similar? Not quite. I am in 25% tax bracket. If I move to UK, 
I would be in 40% bracket. Also the sales tax in UK is 20% which would 
shock most Americans.

comments.text:
You need to be assertive and almost aggressive when it comes to your 
health. No one can tell you what to do about your own life. If you have a 
doctor who is utterly convinced that the $300 drug work better than the 
$100 drug then take his advice but hehas to give you a reason why the $300 
drug is so much more important for you to take. ﻿
comments.author: ann ann

comments.text:
Ask your doctors for drugs that are cheaper. Don't assume they will give 
you the cheapest drug that works well. I believe doctors should have a list 
of commonly diagnosed illnesses and how much they charge for each illness. 
I also believe that they should have a list of prices for each doctor nurse 
practitioner or physician assistant on display. We spent $3000 in 
healthcare every yearand get nothing for it because I go to the $39 clinics 
and get treatment for basic illnesses. I also go online and self diagnosed 
myself quite often and haven't been to the doctor but three times in the 
past four years.﻿
comments.author: ann ann

comments.text:
Healthcare is broken in America. Insurance companies are like cancer. The 
only way to cure the disease is to operate on it or remove it. We need to 
have them to be forced to become nonprofit and then Out the CEOs annual 
salaries and stock options. We need to have insurance companies competing 
against each other and only then the costs will significantly decrease. 
There is absolutely no reason why Americans should pay 39% of their annual 
towards health care costs.﻿
comments.author: ann ann

comments.text:
Where America has gone wrong is its laissez faire approach to capitalism in 
even the most vital of social services, like healthcare. I get that America 
had this complex where it wanted to prove that capitalism was better than 
communism way back when, but come on. The Soviets went to one extreme, but 
you've simply gone to the other extreme which is just as equally unworkable 
in the long run. Something is going to give very soon.﻿
comments.author: frostyguy1989

comments.text: 1:42 The US is not richer per capita than Switzerland. Just saying.﻿

comments.text: http://www.gofundme.com/o5n4tg﻿
comments.author: Jeffrey Ahsan

comments.text:
I think the amount of money that goes into the entertainment industry - 
which is by far the biggest in the world - and the military is definitely 
also a contributor versus the amount that goes into health care and the 
fact that the population of the US is larger than the combined populations 
of Canada, the UK and France, but of course this is a multifaceted issue.﻿
comments.author: Ania D

comments.text:
Somehow I got snared into a discussion of the ACA health care with a guy 
who claimed "America has the best health care in the world" and twisted 
every statement I made into support for his position.

FWIW, most of what I know about health care in the U.S. and other countries 
is in this video.  I've gleaned some other stuff from the news (and BBC 
programming) but this summarizes most of it.

Also FWIW, I still maintain the ACA (a.k.a. Obamacare, a.k.a. Romneycare 
before he ran for president) is on the whole a slight improvement but props 
up a broken system based on private insurance and runaway costs.  Other 
countries systems have their own problems, but if I were a betting man I'd 
wager that few if any people in those countries have to choose between 
buying medication and paying bills.﻿
comments.author: Frank Mitchell

comments.text:
That is not *entirely* true. In Denmark, certain kinds of medication are 
not part of your public health insurance if you are below a certain age 
threshold.

I had one acquaintance that couldn't always pay for his medication against 
schizophrenia.

The problem is that there's a boom of depression and psychosis in young 
people in Denmark (I believe it is in the entire Western world, but I'm 
unsure), so the expenses are high, and there's a huge amount of political 
apathy to change anything.

Mental illness is not sexy in politics.
comments.author: Kasper Brohus Allerslev

comments.text:
So, the clear conclusion is that universal socialized healthcare is cheaper 
and provides better outcomes. Gosh, I wonder if that's why ever other 
civilized country (if we can apply that title to the USA) has adopted some 
form of universal single-payer care. The supreme irony is that we're 
supposed to be the nation who epitomizes practicality.﻿
comments.author: Paul Zink

comments.text:
The real question is: why doesn't the free market do it's job here? 
competition should push prices down isn't it ?﻿
comments.author: UT DO

comments.text: I guess our sources disagree.
comments.author: Michael Tarnpoll

comments.text:
+Michael Tarnpoll It's not just top 5 for breast and prostate cancers, it's 
#1. And by the way, US made to every top 5 list of cancer survival rate. US 
performed above OECD average in most cancers except for lung cancers. 
There're a lot of charts to talk about, so I'm just making it short.

And by the way, there're also statistic for other medical procedure too. US 
performed above OECD average in knee and hip replacement surgery. Also, 
about renal failure treatment, US only ranked behind Japan in dialysis and 
ranked #2 in renal transplant success. Include cataract surgery in also, 
because US also excels at that. The mortality rate of patient admitted for 
acute myocardial infarction for US is also lower than OECD average, and 
performed better than UK. There also success in ischemic stroke mortality 
rate too. Countries that do better than OECD average are considered to be 
"good" at that criteria.

It's concluded that US' primary healthcare is poor compared to other OECD 
countries, but tend to do quite well in more complex healthcare. It didn't 
mean that US' healthcare is good as in term of price and coverage, but this 
shows that US has a lot of saving graces to talk about. We only hear about 
negative side, so no harm talking about positives.

Here is the source for you to analyze yourself, because it's too long to be 
summarize here on Youtube comment section.

http://www.oecd.org/els/health-systems/49105858.pdf
comments.author: Mickey G

comments.text:
+UT DO "Socialism is about distributing wealth created by productive people 
to unproductive people.." This is not correct. If you replaced 
'unproductive people' with 'all of the people' you would be right. Good 
discussion though.
comments.author: Ross Anderson

comments.text:
Actually, Mickey; no. The countries with the highest cancer survival rate 
are France and Japan. The US is not near the top except for breast and 
prostate cancers in which we are in the top five. Also, cancer is one of so 
many factors that affect these health care studies. it would be possible to 
have the best survival rate for cancer and yet be far from it in terms of 
overall health care delivery and quality.
comments.author: Michael Tarnpoll

comments.text:
+Mickey G You might survive cancer, but probably not survive the crippling 
debt from medical expenses
comments.author: HK Chan

comments.text:
+Michael Tarnpoll Actually according to OECD studies, US has the highest 
cancer survival rate out of any OECD nations.
comments.author: Mickey G

comments.text:
+UT DO 1. Information asymmetry between patients (consumer) and providers.
2. Decision on how much healthcare patients need is, in large part, 
depended on healthcare providers - supplier can induce demand, so demand 
and supply are not independent as it should.


The two reasons above are enough to explain why the market fails here.


One additional point, when you let healthcare providers compete, they 
didn't compete to lower the price but rather invested in the costly medical 
technologies. This pushes the price up. And they don't need to sell 
healthcare technologies to the poor as long as they can take as much as 
from the rich because of #2 providers can induce healthcare demand.
comments.author: Udomsak Saengow

comments.text:
Dude, I'm a libertarian but free market sucks here. Its because of the 
rules and regulations that the government puts on economy and business. 
Like it limits the free market and thus making it not free. If you wanna 
learn more about this stuff totally check Inequality for All on netfix, it 
makes it much easier to understand.
comments.author: Amrit Dhillon

comments.text:
I have to disagree; it is not controversial in the least. In virtually all 
of the industrialized world, Europe, the Netherlands, Japan, Russia, all 
offer universal health care and in some cases, mandatory insurance 
supplemented by the government. It should be noted that in these same 
countries, with the exception of Russia, the health of the citizens and the 
health care delivery system is superior to that in the US.
comments.author: Michael Tarnpoll

comments.text:
+UT DO Erm... yes. Though I don't think universal healthcare is 
controversial anywhere in the industrialised world, but calling the nazi 
controversial is a bit of an understatement. But nevermind.
I would argue, like John, that universal healthcare creates competition. 
Since the government has lowered the maximum reimbursement for glasses, 
manufacturers have made a lot of efforts to reduce their prices. Now, you 
can buy frame and lenses for 30€! And since I have a good salary and an 
excellent supplementary mutual insurance, paid by my employer, I got a 
high-end pair for free (and yes I know it's not free but you get the idea). 
Everyone can see properly with a minimum cost for the universal insurance, 
and I still get my expensive glasses thanks to my hard work.
comments.author: Tanatoast

comments.text:
+Tanatoast There is no invisible hand when the market isn't free.
You are talking about democraty, hitler was brought democraticly to power, 
i am not democrat, the voice of the majority has no value in itself.
comments.author: UT DO

comments.text:
It makes you wonder where is the invisible hand. Even though I don't like 
the conspiracy thing, I can't find another explanation than corrupt 
politicians and pharmaceutical/practitioner cartel. 5k$ for a trip in 
ambulance or a CT scan is ridiculous. On your thoughts on socialism, you 
use the words productive and unproductive which reflects of a certain state 
of mind. You could also use autonomous and vulnerable. Anyway, if universal 
healthcare is adopted in a democracy, it is the result of the people's 
will. Since everyone can't be part of the autonomous regarding healthcare 
costs (especially in the US), I think it's the decent thing to do. I don't 
like the idea of putting someone in a wheel chair for the rest of his life 
because he can't afford to pay hip replacement. Finally, the US don't have 
to go full socialised on healthcare. We have a two thirds system where I 
live: the universal healthcare takes all of the vital treatments in charge 
and a percentage of the rest (glasses, tooth prosthesis, etc.). The people 
are free to subscribe to a supplementary insurance owned by shareholders or 
policyholders (the later being generally cheaper and more efficient).

comments.text:
Excellent post.  Poignant and succinct.  I would also like to add an 
observation.  Perhaps one of the reasons why all of this occurs in the land 
of the free is that Americans are in general accepting of the idea that 
healthcare, like anything else should follow a regular business model. 
 Unfortunately, the goal of any business is to make money and this has 
nothing to do with creating a healthy populace.  "Keep the government's 
hands off my healthcare"!  You are right, much better to put decisions 
about what products or procedures I may be reimbursed for to be put in the 
hands of a private corporation that would lose money by paying for them. 
 Any government (which would actually benefit from having a healthy 
populace financially) would be less likely to have my interests in mind? 
 Please.  "The government is so inefficient that It would become even more 
expensive"!  You think?  I doubt it, but would be willing to take the 
chance just the same.  Even if it did, if it meant that everyone had equal 
and adequate coverage, I would be OK with it.  Who says the government 
can't "lose" money on healthcare (at least in the short run)?  Perhaps that 
is another idiosyncrasy of Americans, people who don't work for it, don't 
deserve coverage.  Of course, they themselves may be one illness away from 
losing their own homes, but that would never happen to them!﻿

treated fairly.

comments.author: darkenergylambda

comments.text:
I think a lot of the issue is control.  There's an age-old saying that goes 
like this: "He who pays the bills, makes the rules."  Americans don't want 
to give the government the power to set arbitrary limits on their 
healthcare, such as saying that any cancer patient with a chance of 
survival of 5% or less can no longer get treatment (as is done, I'm told, 
in Britain).  We've just heard too many American-style stories of people 
who either beat the odds, or were mistakenly assigned such low odds in the 
first place.

Also, there is a way in which healthcare is most certainly an industry.  
I'm talking about the sense of the word "industry" that means "hard work."  
It takes hard work to become a medical professional.  If you want to become 
a doctor, here's how it works here in the USA:  You work hard for four 
years, trying your absolute hardest to get your best grades while staying 
involved in extracurriculars, then go take an extremely difficult test 
called the Medical College Admissions Test (MCAT).  Maybe you even take a 
specialized MCAT prep course.  Then, once you've gotten into med school (IF 
you make it), your hard work is only beginning.  If you choose to become a 
specialist, you may find that by the time you're finished with your 
training, you've cut off the first EIGHT TO TEN YEARS of your adult earning 
career when compared with your peers who went into other industries.  
They've graduated, got jobs, married, started families, and here you are 
just getting out of college and starting at the entry level in your 
career.  OF COURSE you want to get paid well, to make up for lost time and 
for lots of hard work in medical school for which you were not paid at the 
time.

If you want to become another type of medical professional, you won't spend 
as long in school, but you'll still have to take lots of classes that would 
be considered "hard" by the average college student's standards, such as 
anatomy and physiology, organic chemistry, and the like.  People sacrifice 
quite a bit to become the highly-trained pros we have here in the USA, and 
the Law of Supply says that the only way to have a good supply of people 
who are willing to walk this road is to pay them well.﻿
comments.author: Philip McNiel

comments.text:
The problem in the U.S. is not the lack of centralized negotiation, but the 
lack of competition. The same government who stifles competition should not 
be called upon to solve the problem by increasing its role. Get rid of 
anti-competition legislation at ALL levels of government, and prices will 
fall. ﻿
comments.author: Paul Jacobs

comments.text:
I found this very interesting and  informative.  I am a Canadian, by the 
way.  The part about the cost for getting a colonoscopy perked my ears up 
as I had one ordered by a former family doctor.  $1100 in the U.S and over 
$655 in Switzerland?  I didn't pay one cent for mine.  Now, I did have to 
wait a couple of months to have it done, but it was more preventative 
medicine than an actual emergency, so the amount of time didn't bother me. 
 While we enjoy "free" health care in Canada, most of us still pay through 
deductions though our employer.  It is not a perfect system and sometimes 
wait times can be a royal pain in the butt, however, I can't imagine living 
in a first world country without any affordable health coverage.  ﻿

comments.text:
I think most of what you presented are symptoms of a long term problem 
which you do not address. The elephant in the room is employer provided 
health insurance. The rate of adoption of employer provided health 
insurance coincides with the dramatic increase in cost of health care. This 
fact underlines the one point where you come close, that people can no 
longer negotiate the price of health care but its BECAUSE they are insured. 
There is no market price discovery at all! Prices for health care are not 
only high, they are INSANE. Even if you ARE insured( a fact which you 
mention.) Pointing out the fact that European countries have cheaper 
healthcare does not mean that it is cheap as it should be. Have you heard 
of the socialist calculation problem?  It basically states that with out a 
market a socialist system (like the healthcare in these European countries) 
would have no way of figuring out what the price of a good or service 
should be. I firmly believe there needs to be real price discovery (not 
government driven) for healthcare costs ever to recover.﻿
comments.author: torq21

comments.text:
I had no idea for the longest time, even after watching a ton of these, 
that this is the guy that writes all those books that my girlfriend loves. 
Crazy coincidence.
But on a note more related to the video, I completely agree and believe 
that really not nearly enough people know or realize this, and often times 
end up blaming the opposite political party anyways. Way to go America. 
Blame the people you disagree with. I think it would do us all a lot more 
good if a lot more people were able to see this video.
I also think that it would do America a whole lot of good to learn more 
about Economy, particularly the Free Market Economy and the enormous good 
it's done this country over the 238 years it's been around.﻿
comments.author: MRGhorm1379
